continent.name: Anger
continent.desc: The angry actions vary not only in their strength, but also in how they deal with what triggered the anger.

states.name: Annoyance
states.desc: The mildest state of anger, never felt very strongly.

states.name: Frustration
states.desc: Losing patience with a person or task that is generating an overload of frustration.

states.name: Argumentativeness
states.desc: Inclined to partake in unfriendly verbal disagreements.

states.name: Bitterness
states.desc: The residue from having been repeatedly angry, usually due to feeling that the world is populated by people or events that block pursuit of what is important to you.

states.name: Exasperation
states.desc: The feeling of losing patience with a person or task that is generating an overload of frustration.

states.name: Vengefulness
states.desc: A strong desire to harm someone who has harmed you.

states.name: Fury
states.desc: Fury or rage names the highest, most intense state of anger, often resulting in a loss of control. May also result in violent actions.

actions.name: Quarrel
actions.desc: Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.

actions.name: Insult
actions.desc: Disparaging the other person in a offensive or hurtful way, which is likely to escalate the conflict in a way that interferes with resolving the conflict.

actions.name: Undermine
actions.desc: To make (someone or something) weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.

actions.name: Dispute
actions.desc: Disagree in a manner that may escalate the dispute.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Loss of control in how or what one says during a disagreement; speaking in a loud volume, pitch and tone.

actions.name: Use physical force
actions.desc: Use of physical force to get one's way, which may be deliberately chosen or the result of a loss of control over how one acts.

actions.name: Set limits
actions.desc: Encapsulate the boundaries of disagreement, seeking to inhibit escalation.

actions.name: Be firm
actions.desc: Convey that one's position is strongly held, not likely to be abandoned.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: To physically or mentally leave the scene of the conflict or threat.

actions.name: Take a time out
actions.desc: Announce intention to withdraw, to prevent escalation of the conflict.

actions.name: Breathe
actions.desc: Focusing awareness on breathing in order to diminish angry or fearful feelings.

actions.name: Practice patience
actions.desc: Regard the conflict as an opportunity to not lose one's temper.

actions.name: Reframe
actions.desc: Reconsidering the emotional trigger in an attempt to reduce or eliminate it.

actions.name: Suppress
actions.desc: Trying to avoid feeling or acting upon the emotion that is being experienced.

actions.name: Distract
actions.desc: Engaging in other activities in an attempt to avoid feeling this emotion.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: To either physically stay away from (someone or something); or internally keep oneâ€™s mind away from what is triggering the anger.

actions.name: Simmer/Brood
actions.desc: Acting in a way that makes clear that angry actions are building or being contemplated.

actions.name: Passive Aggressiveness
actions.desc: Indirect actions that have an angry undercurrent.

actions.name: Remove the Interference
actions.desc: Attempting to eliminate whatever is blocking the pursuit of a goal.

triggers: Being put down by an authority figure

moods.name: Irritability
moods.desc: Irritability is a an angry mood. It is characterized by a readiness, a need to become angry, filtering perceptions to see provocations not noticed when not irritable. The cause is usually not known to the irritable person, but they may know that they are in  such a mood. Frequent bouts of anger occur when irritable, which are more intense and last longer than they would when not irritable.

continent.name: Fear
continent.desc: Fear is the response to perceived danger.

states.name: Trepidation
states.desc: Sensing slight danger, often pending but not immediate.

states.name: Nervousness
states.desc: Perceiving a danger that you do not know how to respond to.

states.name: Anxiety
states.desc: Apprehensiveness about an anticipated or unspecified threat.

states.name: Dread
states.desc: Anticipating severe danger from which there is no protection or escape.

states.name: Desperation
states.desc: Realizing the futility of our attempts to reduce danger.

states.name: Panic
states.desc: A consequence of desperation.

states.name: Horror
states.desc: A mixture of fear and disgust which probably alternate quickly rather than merge together.

states.name: Terror
states.desc: The most extreme fear that can be felt.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: To physically or mentally leave the scene of the threat.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: To physically stay away from someone or something or deliberately not think about it.

actions.name: Hesitate
actions.desc: To hold back in doubt or indecision, often momentarily.

actions.name: Freeze
actions.desc: To become incapable of acting or speaking.

actions.name: Scream/yell
actions.desc: Losing control of how or what one says.

actions.name: Reframe
actions.desc: Reconsidering the emotional trigger as an attempt to reduce or eliminate it.

actions.name: Be Mindful
actions.desc: Accepting how you feel and recognizing that it's temporary.

actions.name: Breathe
actions.desc: Focusing awareness on breathing in order to diminish fearful feelings.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: To repetitively rethink about the emotional experience.

actions.name: Worry
actions.desc: Anticipating the possibility of harm.

actions.name: Distract
actions.desc: Engaging in other activities in an attempt to avoid feeling this emotion.

moods.name: Apprehensiveness
moods.desc: Expecting harm but not knowing how to avoid it. Perceive threats when they are not there, or magnify the seriousness of a threat.

continent.name: Disgust
continent.desc: We are disgusted by anything that is literally or physically toxic.

states.name: Aversion
states.desc: Wanting to avoid something noxious.

states.name: Dislike
states.desc: An aversion to something, some person or some action.

states.name: Distaste
states.desc: Offended by taste or smell and metaphorically used to descrive offensive sights or actions.

states.name: Repugnance
states.desc: Repelled by something toxic, literally or figuratively.

states.name: Loathing
states.desc: Very intense disgust. Very objectionable to be the target of loathing.

states.name: Revulsion
states.desc: Very strong disgust which usually implies a movement away from the source.

states.name: Abhorrence
states.desc: Extremely repelled by look, smell, or taste of toxic sustances, or by highly offensive actions.

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: To physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.

actions.name: Avoid
actions.desc: To either phsyically stay away from (someone or something); or internally keep one's mind away from what is triggering the disgust.

actions.name: Vomit
actions.desc: Literally to expel material from the mouth or stomach; metaphorically denotes very intense disgust.

actions.name: Dehumanize
actions.desc: To treat someone as though he or she is not a human being; to deprive of human qualities, personality, or spirit.

triggers: Anything coming out of the body
Fan's of an opposing sport's team

moods.name: Sour
moods.desc: Not commonly a mood, it can occur as a mood when there is a generalized feeling of repugnance or revulsion - usually of low intensity.

continent.name: Sadness
continent.desc: We experience sadness with the actual or perceived loss of a person to whom we are attached, such as an offspring, a lover, close friend, or to a loss of our own health or social status or to the loss of an object that we value highly.

states.name: Disappointment
states.desc: Felt when expectations are not met.

states.name: Distraughtness
states.desc: Agitated sadness. Felt intensely and often for long periods.

states.name: Discouragement
states.desc: Felt when no way to cope with an acutal or potential loss is known.

states.name: Resignation
states.desc: Accepting that nothing can be done to prevent an important loss.

states.name: Helplessness
states.desc: Realization of the inability to prevent or cope with loss.

states.name: Misery
states.desc: Intense prolonged feelings of anguished sadness.

states.name: Grief
states.desc: Anguished sadness aroused by the death of a loved one. Varies over time, from very intense at the time of the death to intermittent moderate as time goes on.

states.name: Despair
states.desc: Resigned anguished sadness.

states.name: Sorrow
states.desc: Feeling an important loss.

states.name: Anguish
states.desc: Intense agitation. Protesting form of despair over an actual or expected loss.

states.name: Hopelessness
states.desc: NEED DESCRIPTION

actions.name: Seek Comfort
actions.desc: To seek help or support from others

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: To physically or mentally leave the scene.

actions.name: Ruminate
actions.desc: To compulsively, repetitively, rethink about the emotional experience.

actions.name: Mourn
actions.desc: To focus on the loss.

actions.name: Protest
actions.desc: To complain about the loss albeit knowing that the complaint will not recover what was lost.

actions.name: Feel Ashamed
actions.desc: To feel the need to hide how one feels about what or who is lost.

actions.name: Distract
actions.desc: Engaging in other activities in an attempt to avoid feeling this emotion.

triggers: Not being invited to a party

moods.name: Dysphoria (or feeling blue)
moods.desc: Feelings of resignation, discouragement, or disappointment that endure for a long time period. The anguished side of sadness does not transform into a mood.

continent.name: Enjoyment
continent.desc: The pursuit of what feels good is a primary motive in our lives.

states.name: Sensory Pleasures
states.desc: NEED DESCRIPTION

states.name: Relief
states.desc: When something expected to be unplesant, especialy the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.

states.name: Amusement
states.desc: Light, playful, humorous feelings of enjoyment.

states.name: Excitement
states.desc: Energetic pursuit that, unlike other enjoyable emotions, is rarely felt slightly, but ranges from mid to high in intesnity. May merge with any of the emotions generate a very active form of that emotion.

states.name: Ecstasy
states.desc: Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.

states.name: Fiero
states.desc: An Italian word that descrives the enjoyment felt when you have met a challenge that stretched your capabilities.

states.name: Naches
states.desc: The Yiddish word for feelings of pride in the accomplishments, or sometimes just the existence, of your actual offspring, or mentored offspring. Crucial for motivating the nurture of infants and children.

states.name: Wonder
states.desc: Experiencing something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing, or hard to believe.

states.name: Schadenfreude
states.desc: Enjoying the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.

states.name: Rejoicing
states.desc: A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see acts of human goodness, kindness, and compassion. Also called elevation.

states.name: Compassion-joy
states.desc: Enjoyment felt when you act compassionately, especially if your actions helpf to relieve another person's suffering.

states.name: Pride
states.desc: Wanting others to know the pleasure you feel in your own accomplishments or the accomplishments of another who you either nurtured directly or identified with.

states.name: Debauchery
states.desc: NEED DESCRIPTION

actions.name: Withdraw
actions.desc: To physically or mentally leave the scene.

actions.name: Seek more
actions.desc: To increase the enjoyable feelings.

actions.name: Maintain
actions.desc: To continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.

actions.name: Gloat
actions.desc: To enjoy others envying your enjoyable state.

actions.name: Exclaim
actions.desc: To vocally express enjoyment to others.

actions.name: Engage/Connect
actions.desc: To desire connection and engagement with others to share in feelings of enjoyment.

actions.name: Savor
actions.desc: To relish in the experience of good feelings about the felt and psychological experiences.

actions.name: Indulge
actions.desc: Excessively engaging in the enjoyable feelings

moods.name: High
moods.desc: Generalized, non-specific feeling good not about any trigger; lasting hours.

intro.header: Welcome to The Ekman Atlas of Emotion
intro.body:
This collection of maps was created to help you better understand your emotions, where they come from and the effect they have on your life.

Navigate the atlas by scrolling between sections, and by clicking elements to dig deeper.

This is an opportunity for you to explore the vast world of emotions. The atlas begins with what scholars agree on and gradually introduces our working hypotheses of more complex subject matter.

continents.body: Each emotion is represented as a continent. The movement of the shapes reflects how our emotions vary in strength and frequency in peoples lives.

states.body: Each emotion names a number of related but different states. These states vary not only in their nature, but in their intensity.

actions.body: Each emotional state typically results in a number of actions.

qualities.body: Actions that further future collaboration with others.
Actions that decrease the likelihood of being able to collaborate with others.
Sometimes an action can be both constructive and desctructive in different contexts.

triggers.body: Triggers automatically bring forth an emotion without consideration.

steps.body: Some triggers are universal, some are cultural, and some are individual.
We can become emotional about anything: the world around us, both novel and familiar, our expectations and memories.
It is very difficult to modify our emotional actions once triggered. Identifying what triggers our emotions may enable us to lead a more balanced emotional life.
Universal triggers are innate, common to everyone. They affect us more intensely than learned triggers.
Learned triggers are either cultural, stemming from widely shared experiences, or personal, arising from more individual experiences.

moods.body: Moods are longer-lasting cousins of an emotion that cause the related emotion to be felt more frequently and intensely.
